captions.text:
In mid 1905, Albert Einstein derived what
is now the most famous equation in the world:

E equals M C squared. But he didn't just write
this down out of the blue – it followed

directly from his paper on special relativity
that we talked about in last week's video…
and here's how he did it:

Suppose you're watching a cat float freely
in empty space, when suddenly it emits a flash

of light in all directions. The light carries
away some energy, we'll call it "E", so by

conservation of energy the cat must have lost
energy E… but since the light was emitted

symmetrically in all directions, it won't
have changed the cat's velocity. So where
did the energy for the light come from?

Never mind that now… let's imagine you get
bored and zoom off in a spaceship in the middle

of the experiment. But from your new perspective,
you're sitting still in your spaceship and

the cat is the one moving past outside the
window! Therefore you'll calculate that the

cat has some kinetic energy, that is, energy
of motion… and when you see the cat emit

the flash of light, you'll again measure that
its energy decreases by the energy of the
light.

Except now that you're moving, special relativity
tells us that time passes at different rates

for you and the cat, so you'll measure a different
value for the frequency, and thus energy of

the flash of light. This is the relativistic
doppler effect, and for our purposes, it amounts

to multiplying the energy of the light by
one plus your velocity squared divided by
twice the speed of light squared.

So to recap, if you take off at velocity v,
you'll see the cat gain some kinetic energy

KE1, then at the flash you'll see the cat's
energy decrease by E times one plus v squared

over two c squared. On the other hand, if
you wait, you'll see the cat's energy decrease

by E, and now when you take off you'll see
it gain kinetic energy KE2.

But this is silly! You never touch or otherwise
influence the cat in either case, so you should

get the same total energy at the end… Rearranging,
we see that the kinetic energy before and

after the flash must be different! And the
kinetic energy of an object is one-half of

its mass times velocity squared, but we know
that the velocity was the same in both cases…

so in order to account for the difference,
the cat's mass must change when it emits the
flash of light!

Now if we cancel things out, you can see that
the change in mass of the cat must be equal

to the energy divided by c squared – or,
as you've heard before, E equals M C squared!

comments.author: Miss Cakelyn

comments.text:
+Miss Cakelyn You're welcome. Yes, i understand what you're saying. The 
equation itself is a very simple algebraic equation. But the equation 
itself is *not* what makes Einstein genius. Einstein made the *original* 
assumption that the 3D world we live in is actually a 3D embedding in a 4D 
world he called "spacetime". For example, what you see in the screen of 
your computer is a 2D embedding in a (apparent) 3D world. 

E=m₀c², as simple as it is, follows from this "spacetime" setting. Although 
it can be "derived" in numerous ways that often obscure this important 
point.
comments.author: LeconsdAnalyse

comments.text:
+LeconsdAnalyse
Okay, thank you. But the thing I still don't understand is also why It's 
considered genius when so many people know how it works. If everyone knows 
it and can explain it then how can it be considered complex or genius? I 
can do 1 + 1, almost everyone can do it, and almost everyone can explain it 
and that's not considered genius is it?
comments.author: Miss Cakelyn

comments.text:
+Miss Cakelyn Good question.

Before there was Special Relativity a free (of external fields) mass 
particle (conservative system) moving with speed v (v/c<<1) had mechanical 
energy, E=½m₀v² -*(a)*. Where m₀ is the rest mass of the particle.
Then came SR and the equation E=mc²=m₀c²/√(1 - v²/c²) -*(b)*, for a free 
mass particle moving with relativistic speed v (v/c~1). 

Next we need the following Taylor series (which in this case is also an 
asymptotic series), 1/√(1±x²) = 1∓½x²+(1·3)/(2·4)x⁴∓..., (|x|<1). 
Using the minus case, substituting x=v/c, and keeping only the *first two 
terms*, we get from *(b)*: E~m₀c² + ½m₀v² -*(c)* (when v/c<<1). 

Notice that *(c)* has an extra term compared to *(a)* and when v=0, E=m₀c². 
This is the equation that appears in the clip above, and the reason why it 
is "genius". Namely, Einstein's theory of Special Relativity predicts an *additional 
energy* (m₀c²) present even when v=0, and first proven experimentally by 
the Cockcroft-Walton experiment 
http://www.aip.org/history/mod/fission/fission1/02.html

comments.author: HaydenHatTrick

comments.text:
Poorly presented and flawed explanation. They try to be cute and state that 
“you get bored and zoom off in your spaceship in the middle of the (cat) 
experiment.” They draw a spaceship clearly flying AWAY from the cat (Lowest 
order Doppler term would then be (1 – v/c)). Next they state there is a 
relativistic Doppler shift of 1 + 0.5*v^2/c^2/2 (What happened to the (1 – 
v/c) term when you are moving AWAY from the cat?) 

Later on, if you look carefully, you will see that they now show the 
spaceship shooting PAST the cat at the exact moment the light is emitted 
(NOT moving away from the cat as previously shown). They needlessly 
confused the poor viewer with a sloppy explanation/setup of Einstein’s 
thought experiment. 

They need to spend less time on being cute in their explanation and more 
time being unambiguous in the physical set up of the derivation. ﻿
comments.author: James Mark

comments.text:
The "Doppler" effect is a theory, with quite a bit of evidence to indicate 
it is just more pseudo-science. The real *mistake* is contained in E=MC² 
when those same pseudo-scientists claim Black Holes exist, which is 
forbidden in Special Relativity, unless you think anything can be an 
infinite point mass by ignoring SR. The other stupid claim is Ric=Ricμν=0 
establishes a space/time continuum by removing material sources from 
Gμν=-κTμν and then saying that the "fabric" is outside the material source! 
Circular arguments are the meat for pseudo-science in today's "physics" - 
take the body out and then back in to save gravity as a petty god ...
comments.author: tongmaa

comments.text:
+LeconsdAnalyse Yes, he sounds like a nice guy, but that's beside the 
point. One does not make it as simple as possible by talking to the 
audience like they are children and then drawing pictures that improperly 
set the stage for the derivation. Perhaps, I'm wrong about this, but I 
believe the derivation is based on someone moving past the cat just as it 
is emitting light. The earlier (first) drawing shows the spaceship moving 
AWAY from the cat. 

Replacing the cat with Winnie the Pooh and raising the voice of the 
narrator to a higher pitch would not make the video easier to understand, 
even though it might be more entertaining to some. On the other hand, 
carefully scrutinizing the description and drawings before posting would 
have helped a great deal. The reason that I’m being hard on someone just 
trying to explain physics is that I wasted a lot of time trying to figure 
things out and feeling stupid the entire time. 

Over two million hits. That is terrific for any kind of video, but 
especially so for educational/science videos. On the other hand, imagine if 
each of those 2 million had to spend an extra 5 minutes (It took me at 
least twice as long as that, but I'm not very smart) to understand the 
derivation because the crucial initial drawing showed the wrong geometry 
for the observer in the spacecraft. That's a hell of a lot of wasted man 
hours!
comments.author: James Mark

comments.text:
That's interesting... the way my book worked this out was by deriving the 
lorentz transformations and then simply working from there to get 
relativistic force and finally energy through its definition (integral of 
force with respect to distance over which it's applied). Also... 
relativistic kinetic energy is (gamma - 1)mc^2... (1/2)mv^2 is only 
supposed to work at low speeds. But if you're at a speed high enough to 
consider the relativistic doppler effect... I feel like some physics might 
be getting mixed up here. But, I don't know; I'm tired and I'd have to 
think about that some more.﻿
